trans-unit.source: Debug an API App in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Debug an API App in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn how to debug an API App while it runs in Azure App Service, using Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to debug an API App while it runs in Azure App Service, using Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Debug an API App in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Debug an API App in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to debug ASP.NET Web API code that is configured to run in an [API app](app-service-api-apps-why-best-platform.md) in [Azure App Service](../app-service/app-service-value-prop-what-is.md).
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to debug ASP.NET Web API code that is configured to run in an [API app](app-service-api-apps-why-best-platform.md) in [Azure App Service](../app-service/app-service-value-prop-what-is.md).

trans-unit.source: You’ll debug both locally and remotely (while it runs in Azure).
trans-unit.target: You’ll debug both locally and remotely (while it runs in Azure).

trans-unit.source: The tutorial works with the API app that you [create](app-service-dotnet-create-api-app.md) and [deploy](app-service-dotnet-deploy-api-app.md) in the previous tutorials in this series.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial works with the API app that you [create](app-service-dotnet-create-api-app.md) and [deploy](app-service-dotnet-deploy-api-app.md) in the previous tutorials in this series.

trans-unit.source: Debug an API app remotely
trans-unit.target: Debug an API app remotely

trans-unit.source: To enable remote debugging, you have to deploy a debug build to Azure.
trans-unit.target: To enable remote debugging, you have to deploy a debug build to Azure.

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio **Solution Explorer**, right-click the project that you deployed in [the previous tutorial](app-service-dotnet-deploy-api-app.md), and select **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio **Solution Explorer**, right-click the project that you deployed in [the previous tutorial](app-service-dotnet-deploy-api-app.md), and select **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Publish Web** dialog, select the **Settings** tab and select the **Debug** build configuration.
trans-unit.target: In the **Publish Web** dialog, select the **Settings** tab and select the **Debug** build configuration.

trans-unit.source: Click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: Publish project
trans-unit.target: Publish project

trans-unit.source: A browser window opens to the base URL of your API app.
trans-unit.target: A browser window opens to the base URL of your API app.

trans-unit.source: In the browser address bar, add /swagger to the end of the URL and press Enter.
trans-unit.target: In the browser address bar, add /swagger to the end of the URL and press Enter.

trans-unit.source: This step assumes that you enabled the Swagger UI as directed in the [create](app-service-dotnet-create-api-app.md) tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This step assumes that you enabled the Swagger UI as directed in the [create](app-service-dotnet-create-api-app.md) tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Swagger UI
trans-unit.target: Swagger UI

trans-unit.source: Return to Visual Studio, and click from **View > Server Explorer**.
trans-unit.target: Return to Visual Studio, and click from **View > Server Explorer**.

trans-unit.source: In **Server Explorer**, expand the **Azure > App Service** node.
trans-unit.target: In **Server Explorer**, expand the **Azure > App Service** node.

trans-unit.source: Locate the resource group that you created or selected when you deployed your API app.
trans-unit.target: Locate the resource group that you created or selected when you deployed your API app.

trans-unit.source: Under the resource group, right-click the node for your API app and select **Attach Debugger**.
trans-unit.target: Under the resource group, right-click the node for your API app and select **Attach Debugger**.

trans-unit.source: Attaching debugger
trans-unit.target: Attaching debugger

trans-unit.source: The remote debugger will try to connect.
trans-unit.target: The remote debugger will try to connect.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, you may need to retry clicking **Attach Debugger** to establish a connection, so if it fails, try again.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, you may need to retry clicking **Attach Debugger** to establish a connection, so if it fails, try again.

trans-unit.source: Attaching debugger
trans-unit.target: Attaching debugger

trans-unit.source: After the connection is established, open the **ContactsController.cs** file in the API App project, and add a breakpoint in the `Get` method.
trans-unit.target: After the connection is established, open the **ContactsController.cs** file in the API App project, and add a breakpoint in the `Get` method.

trans-unit.source: Applying breakpoints to controller
trans-unit.target: Applying breakpoints to controller

trans-unit.source: Return to the browser session, click the **Get** verb to display the schema for the *Contact* object, and then click **Try it Out**.
trans-unit.target: Return to the browser session, click the **Get** verb to display the schema for the *Contact* object, and then click **Try it Out**.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio stops program execution at your breakpoint, and you can debug your controller's logic.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio stops program execution at your breakpoint, and you can debug your controller's logic.

trans-unit.source: Try it out
trans-unit.target: Try it out

trans-unit.source: Debug an API app locally
trans-unit.target: Debug an API app locally

trans-unit.source: There may be times when you want to debug your API app locally; for example, if round-trips to the Azure server make debugging slow.
trans-unit.target: There may be times when you want to debug your API app locally; for example, if round-trips to the Azure server make debugging slow.

trans-unit.source: This section illustrates how to debug your API app locally using the Swagger UI as the test client.
trans-unit.target: This section illustrates how to debug your API app locally using the Swagger UI as the test client.

trans-unit.source: In your browser, navigate to the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: In your browser, navigate to the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: Click the **Browse** button on the sidebar and select **API Apps**.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Browse** button on the sidebar and select **API Apps**.

trans-unit.source: Browse options on Azure portal
trans-unit.target: Browse options on Azure portal

trans-unit.source: From the list of API apps in your subscription, select the API app you created.
trans-unit.target: From the list of API apps in your subscription, select the API app you created.

trans-unit.source: API App List
trans-unit.target: API App List

trans-unit.source: In the API app's blade, click the **API app host**.
trans-unit.target: In the API app's blade, click the **API app host**.

trans-unit.source: API App Host
trans-unit.target: API App Host

trans-unit.source: In the API app host's blade, click **All Settings**.
trans-unit.target: In the API app host's blade, click **All Settings**.

trans-unit.source: API App Host All Settings
trans-unit.target: API App Host All Settings

trans-unit.source: In the **Settings** blade, click **Application settings**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Settings** blade, click **Application settings**.

trans-unit.source: API App Host Application Settings
trans-unit.target: API App Host Application Settings

trans-unit.source: In the **Web app settings** blade, scroll down to the **App settings** section.
trans-unit.target: In the **Web app settings** blade, scroll down to the **App settings** section.

trans-unit.source: API App Host Application Settings for Local Debug
trans-unit.target: API App Host Application Settings for Local Debug

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the API app project's *web.config* file.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the API app project's *web.config* file.

trans-unit.source: From **App settings**, add each of the following keys and values to the *web.config* file's **appSettings** section.
trans-unit.target: From **App settings**, add each of the following keys and values to the *web.config* file's **appSettings** section.

trans-unit.source: EMA\_MicroserviceId
trans-unit.target: EMA\_MicroserviceId

trans-unit.source: EMA\_Secret
trans-unit.target: EMA\_Secret

trans-unit.source: EMA\_RuntimeUrl
trans-unit.target: EMA\_RuntimeUrl

trans-unit.source: When you're done, the **appSettings** section of your *web.config* should resemble the following screenshot.
trans-unit.target: When you're done, the **appSettings** section of your *web.config* should resemble the following screenshot.

trans-unit.source: API App Host Application Settings for Local Debug
trans-unit.target: API App Host Application Settings for Local Debug

trans-unit.source: **Note:** The *EMA_* values you added to your *web.config* file in this section contain sensitive authorization information.
trans-unit.target: **Note:** The *EMA_* values you added to your *web.config* file in this section contain sensitive authorization information.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, it is recommended that you avoid saving these values in a public source control repository.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, it is recommended that you avoid saving these values in a public source control repository.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Best practices for deploying passwords and other sensitive data to ASP.NET and Azure App Service](http://www.asp.net/identity/overview/features-api/best-practices-for-deploying-passwords-and-other-sensitive-data-to-aspnet-and-azure).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Best practices for deploying passwords and other sensitive data to ASP.NET and Azure App Service](http://www.asp.net/identity/overview/features-api/best-practices-for-deploying-passwords-and-other-sensitive-data-to-aspnet-and-azure).

trans-unit.source: Place a breakpoint in your API app's controller code in the `Get` method.
trans-unit.target: Place a breakpoint in your API app's controller code in the `Get` method.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to start a Visual Studio debugging session.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to start a Visual Studio debugging session.

trans-unit.source: If the API app's access level is set to **Public (anonymous)**, you can use the Swagger UI page to test.
trans-unit.target: If the API app's access level is set to **Public (anonymous)**, you can use the Swagger UI page to test.

trans-unit.source: If the API app's access level is set to **Public (authenticated)**, you'll need to authenticate and use a browser tool following the procedures shown in [Protect an API app](app-service-api-dotnet-add-authentication.md#use-postman-to-send-a-post-request) for a Post request, that is:
trans-unit.target: If the API app's access level is set to **Public (authenticated)**, you'll need to authenticate and use a browser tool following the procedures shown in [Protect an API app](app-service-api-dotnet-add-authentication.md#use-postman-to-send-a-post-request) for a Post request, that is:

trans-unit.source: Go to the gateway login URL and enter credentials to log in.
trans-unit.target: Go to the gateway login URL and enter credentials to log in.

trans-unit.source: Get the Zumo token value from the x-zumo-auth cookie.
trans-unit.target: Get the Zumo token value from the x-zumo-auth cookie.

trans-unit.source: Add an x-zumo-auth header to your request, and set its value to the x-zumo-auth cookie value.
trans-unit.target: Add an x-zumo-auth header to your request, and set its value to the x-zumo-auth cookie value.

trans-unit.source: Submit the request.
trans-unit.target: Submit the request.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** When you're running locally, Azure cannot control access to the API app to ensure that only authenticated users can execute its methods.
trans-unit.target: **Note:** When you're running locally, Azure cannot control access to the API app to ensure that only authenticated users can execute its methods.

trans-unit.source: When you run in Azure, all traffic intended for the API app is routed through the gateway, and the gateway doesn't pass on unauthenticated requests.
trans-unit.target: When you run in Azure, all traffic intended for the API app is routed through the gateway, and the gateway doesn't pass on unauthenticated requests.

trans-unit.source: There is no redirection when you run locally, which means that unauthenticated requests are not prevented from accessing the API app.
trans-unit.target: There is no redirection when you run locally, which means that unauthenticated requests are not prevented from accessing the API app.

trans-unit.source: The value of authenticating as described above is that you can successfully execute authentication-related code in the API app, such as code that retrieves information about the logged-on user.
trans-unit.target: The value of authenticating as described above is that you can successfully execute authentication-related code in the API app, such as code that retrieves information about the logged-on user.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how the gateway handles authentication for API apps, see [Authentication for API apps and mobile apps](../app-service/app-service-authentication-overview.md#azure-app-service-gateway).
trans-unit.target: For more information about how the gateway handles authentication for API apps, see [Authentication for API apps and mobile apps](../app-service/app-service-authentication-overview.md#azure-app-service-gateway).

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you've seen how to debug API Apps.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you've seen how to debug API Apps.

trans-unit.source: For more troubleshooting information, see [Troubleshoot a web app in Azure App Service using Visual Studio](../app-service-web/web-sites-dotnet-troubleshoot-visual-studio.md).
trans-unit.target: For more troubleshooting information, see [Troubleshoot a web app in Azure App Service using Visual Studio](../app-service-web/web-sites-dotnet-troubleshoot-visual-studio.md).

trans-unit.source: Because API apps are web apps that have additional features for hosting web services, you can use the same debugging and troubleshooting tools for API apps that you use for web apps.
trans-unit.target: Because API apps are web apps that have additional features for hosting web services, you can use the same debugging and troubleshooting tools for API apps that you use for web apps.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
